page.title: 04Landscape _ Drainage
page.content: The River Parrett is tidal and for hundreds of years man has had to resort to various devices to prevent flooding. The banks of the river have been heightened to contain the river in its course but this is inadequate when tides are abnormal and heavy rains have fallen on the surrounding fields. To cope with the excess water {CLYCE} systems operate. The pressure of water inside the river course at high tide closes a metal hinged flap attached to a pipe which in turn is fed into a { {rhine }or ditch. Inland flood water is contained in this rhine until low tide when the pressure of water in the rhine forces open the metal flap and is admitted to the river channel.
